metadata.title: ECS Health, Safety and Environmental Assessment

categories.name: General Health and Safety at Work

questions.question: What do the letters CDM stand for?
answers: Control of Demolition and Management Regulations
questions.explanation: The CDM Regulations impose duties to manage construction projects, ensure physical safeguards are provided to prevent danger during such projects and that adequate welfare facilities are provided.

questions.question: Identify one method of enforcing regulations that are available to the Health and Safety Executive:
questions.explanation: Improvement notices require action to achieve standards which meet health and safety law.

questions.question: What happens if a Prohibition Notice is issued by an Inspector of the local authority or the HSE?
answers: The work in hand can be completed, but no new work started
The work can continue if adequate safety precautions are put in place
The work that is subject to the notice must cease
The work can continue, provided a risk assessment is carried out
questions.explanation: The work activity covered by a prohibition notice must cease, until the identified danger is removed.

questions.question: Health and Safety Executive Inspector can?
answers: Only visit if they have made an appointment
Only visit if accompanied by the principal contractor
Only visit to interview the site manager
questions.explanation: Inspectors have a range of powers, including the right to visit premises at any time.

questions.question: Prohibition Notice means:
answers: When you finish the work you must not start again
Work is to stop for that day only
Work may continue until the end of the day
questions.explanation: The work activity covered by the prohibition notice must cease, until the identified danger is removed.

questions.question: In what circumstances can an HSE Improvement Notice be issued?
answers: If there is a breach of legal requirements
Only between Monday and Friday on site
questions.explanation: Improvement notices require action to achieve standards which meet health and safety law.

questions.question: What is an Improvement Notice?
answers: A notice issued by the site principal contractor to tidy up the site
A notice from the client to the principal contractor to speed up the work
A notice issued by a Building Control Officer to deepen foundations
A notice issued by an HSE/local authority Inspector to enforce compliance with health and safety legislation
questions.explanation: Improvement notices require action to achieve standards which meet health and safety law.

questions.question: If a Health and Safety Executive Inspector issues a Prohibition Notice, this means that:
answers: The Site Manager can choose whether or not to ignore the notice
Specific work activities, highlighted on the notice, must stop
The HSE must supervise the work covered by the notice
The HSE must supervise all work from then on
questions.explanation: Prohibition notices are intended to stop activities which can cause serious injury.

questions.question: Employers are required to provide information to their employees on their health and safety rights and responsibilities and how to get advice by:
answers: Telling them verbally when they start work for them
Displaying a poster or giving them leaflets approved by the HSE
Making them read the company health and safety policy
questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the Health and Safety Information for Employees Regulations (as amended).

questions.question: Who is responsible for signing a Company Safety Policy?
questions.explanation: The Health and Safety at Work Act requires the most senior member of management to sign the health and safety policy statement.

questions.question: Which one of the following must be in a company's written Health and Safety Policy?
answers: Aims and objectives of the company
Organisation and arrangements in force for carrying out the health and safety policy
Name of the Health and Safety Adviser
questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: Employers have to produce a written Health and Safety Policy statement when:
answers: They employ five people or more
questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: Companies employing five or more people must have a written Health and Safety Policy because:
answers: The principal contractor gives them work on site
The Social Security Act requires it
questions.explanation: The Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 requires it.

questions.question: What do the letters HSE stand for?
questions.explanation: The Health and Safety Executive was established under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974.

questions.question: The Health and Safety Executive is:
answers: Part of the National Health Service
The regulatory body for the promotion of health and safety at work
The jury in health and safety court cases
questions.explanation: The Health and Safety Executive is part of the Department for Work and Pensions.

questions.question: The Health and Safety at Work Act requires employers to provide what for their employees?
questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of Section 2 of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: The Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 and any regulations made under the Act are:
answers: Not compulsory, but should be complied with if convenient
Practical advice for the employer to follow
questions.explanation: The requirements of health and safety law are mandatory and failure to follow them can lead to prosecution.

questions.question: Under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974, which of the following have a duty to work safely?
questions.explanation: Employers, employees and the self-employed all have duties to work safely under the Act.

questions.question: What is the MAXIMUM penalty that a Higher Court, can currently impose for a breach of the Health and Safety at Work Act?
answers: Unlimited fine and two years' imprisonment
questions.explanation: A Lower Court can impose a fine of up to £20,000 and/or up to six months imprisonment for certain offences. The potential fine in a Higher Court, however, is unlimited and the term of imprisonment can be up to 2 years.

questions.question: What do the letters ACOP stand for?
questions.explanation: An ACOP is a code of practice approved by the Health and Safety Executive (or the Health and Safety Commission prior to April 2008).

questions.question: Where should you look for official advice on health and safety matters?
answers: A set of health and safety guidelines provided by suppliers
The health and safety rules as laid down by the employer
Guidance issued by the Health and Safety Executive
A professionally approved guide book on regulations
questions.explanation: The HSE is the UK enforcing body and its guidance can be regarded as 'official'.

questions.question: Regulations that govern health and safety on construction sites:
answers: Do not apply during 'out of hours' working
questions.explanation: The requirements of health and safety law are mandatory, and failure to follow them can lead to prosecutions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
answers: The duty for health and safety falls only on the employer
All employees must take reasonable care, not only to protect themselves but also their colleagues
Employees have no responsibility for Health and Safety on site
Only the client is responsible for safety on site
questions.explanation: This is a legal requirement under Section 7 of the Health & Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: Who of the following would you expect to be responsible for managing health and safety on site?
questions.explanation: The responsibility for management of health and safety at work rests with the employer.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct for risk assessment?
answers: It is a good idea but not essential
Only required to be done for hazardous work
questions.explanation: There is a legal requirement for all work to be suitably risk assessed.

questions.question: In the context of a risk assessment, what do you understand by the term risk?
answers: Something with the potential to cause injury
Any work activity that can be described as dangerous
The likelihood that harm from a particular hazard will occur
questions.explanation: Hazard and risk are not the same. Risk reflects the chance of being harmed by a hazard.

questions.question: Who would you expect to carry out a risk assessment on your working site?
questions.explanation: A risk assessment must be conducted by a 'competent person'.

questions.question: What is a HAZARD?
answers: Where an accident is likely to happen
Something with the potential to cause harm
The likelihood of something going wrong
questions.explanation: Examples of hazards include: a drum of acid, breeze blocks on an elevated plank; cables running across a floor.

questions.question: What must be done before any work begins?
questions.explanation: This is a legal requirement of the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations.

questions.question: Complete the following sentence: A risk assessment:
answers: Is a piece of paper required by law
Is a means of analysing what might go wrong
questions.explanation: Risk assessment involves a careful review of what can cause harm and the practical measures to be taken to reduce the risk of harm.

questions.question: Why would your supervisor ask you to read the method statement and risk assessment before you start your next job?
answers: They think you have got nothing better to do
The documents contain information on how to carry out the job in a safe manner
They wouldn't as they think they are a waste of time
As someone has taken the time and trouble to write them, you might as well read them
questions.explanation: The supervisor must, by law, keep workers advised of significant risks, and control measures.

questions.question: What do the blue and white health and safety signs tell you?
answers: Where the nearest fire exit is
questions.explanation: Blue and white signs show a 'mandatory' requirement.

questions.question: What colours are emergency exit signs?
questions.explanation: The colours are prescribed in the Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations.

questions.question: What is the main colour on a safety sign stating that you must NOT do something?
questions.explanation: Prohibitory signs are round and feature a black pictogram on a white background with red edging and diagonal line.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a warning, for example 'Fork-lift trucks operating'?
questions.explanation: Warning signs are triangular and feature a black pictogram on a yellow background with black edging.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of safety signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a prohibited activity, for example 'No access for pedestrians'?
questions.explanation: Prohibitory signs are round and feature a black pictogram on a white background with red edging and diagonal line.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of safety signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a mandatory activity, for example 'Safety helmets must be worn'?
questions.explanation: Mandatory signs are round and feature a white pictogram on a blue background.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of safety signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a safe condition, for example First Aid kit?
questions.explanation: Emergency escape and first-aid signs are rectangular or square and feature a white pictogram on a green background.

questions.question: Why should regular inspections of the workplace take place?
answers: To check whether the working environment is safe
To check that all employees are present
To check that everyone is doing their job
To prepare for a visit from an HSE Inspector
questions.explanation: The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations require that routine inspections of workplaces are carried out to ensure that preventative and protective measures are in place and effective.

questions.question: How can you help to prevent accidents?
answers: Know how to get help quickly
Know where the first-aid kit is kept
questions.explanation: Action to improve safety can only be taken if the risk is known about. Employees have a duty of care to other employees.

questions.question: If there is a risk of injury from lifting loads what should you think about first?
answers: Whether the load needs to be lifted at all
What the weight of the load is
Where to hold the load when lifting
questions.explanation: If possible, it is best to avoid the risks from lifting altogether. This is the preferred requirement laid down in the Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992.

questions.question: Before performing manual lifting what is the first thing you should do?
answers: Kick it to see if it is stable
questions.explanation: If you assess the whole task first, you will have a clear idea of possible hazards and how to overcome them, before lifting.

questions.question: Which is the part of your body MOST LIKELY to be injured during a manual handling activity which involves moving a heavy load?
questions.explanation: HSE statistics show that most manual handling injuries are to the back.

questions.question: What should you do if your supervisor asks you to move something that you find is too heavy to lift?
answers: Give it a try using correct lifting methods
Ask your mates to assist in the lift
Inform your supervisor that it is too heavy
Get a forklift truck or lifting tackle
questions.explanation: The HSE advises employees to inform the employer if they identify hazardous handling activities.

questions.question: What would you NOT consider in making a judgement of the risks from a load?
questions.explanation: All others can all affect the difficulty of lifting an object.

questions.question: When moving a load fitted with wheels which of the following is generally true?
answers: Pushing and pulling are equally risky
It is safer to pick it up and carry it
questions.explanation: The operator should try to push rather than pull when moving a load, provided they can see over it and control steering and stopping.

questions.question: A manual handling operation is defined as which one of the following?
questions.explanation: Manual handling covers human effort only.

questions.question: What is the MAXIMUM weight that an individual may lift?
answers: The weight they can lift comfortably
35kg provided that it has no sharp edges
15kg provided that it is a compact load
questions.explanation: There are no strict weight limits – the priority is to avoid injury.

questions.question: What is the most common type of injury resulting from lifting loads from the floor?
questions.explanation: As shown by HSE statistics.

questions.question: Where a load has to be lifted manually, what is the employer required to do by law?
answers: Calculate the cost of the exercise
Determine the number of people required
Assess the risk of the task
Assess the time the job will take
questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of the Manual Handling Operations regulations 1992.

questions.question: Which of the following is advisable when lifting a load manually?
answers: Keep legs straight, bend back, use power of legs
Bend the knees, keep the back straight, use power of back
Bend the knees, keep the back as straight as possible, use power of legs
Keep legs and back straight, use power of legs
questions.explanation: Stooping can increase the stress on the lower back. However, stooping slightly may be preferable to adopting a squatting posture, which can place excessive loads on knees and hips.

questions.question: In manual handling, which of the following general statements is true?
answers: You should keep your back bent when lifting
Anyone can carry any load as long as they are strong enough
Large loads should be broken down into smaller loads where possible
Loads should be held at arm's length while carrying
questions.explanation: This is a recommendation (INDG143).

questions.question: What is the recommended limit for a compact load, that can be safely carried by a fit, male worker?
questions.explanation: This figure is in HSE guidance, and relates to lifting and lowering at elbow height.

questions.question: Where there has been a major change in a manual handling operation, what should the employer do?
answers: Review the number of people involved
questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of the Manual Handling Operations regulations 1992.

questions.question: What should be the first consideration when you are about to lift a load on your own?
answers: Assess whether it is safe to lift it on your own
Ensure you lift with a bent back
questions.explanation: Employees should assess whether there is a risk of injury before lifting. If they are not sure they should seek advice from their supervisor.

questions.question: Which of the following would NOT make a load easier to handle manually?
answers: Securing the load so that it does not shift unexpectedly
Providing suitable handles or hand grips
questions.explanation: Painting it a bright colour would not make it easier to handle.

questions.question: If there is a risk of injury from moving loads what should you think about?
answers: Getting someone to assist you over the distance
questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the Manual Handling Operations regulations 1992.

questions.question: As an approximate guide the manual handling capacity of a two person team is:
answers: The sum of their individual capacities
The capacity of the strongest individual
The capacity of the weakest individual
Two thirds the sum of their individual capacities
questions.explanation: This is contained in HSE guidance on the Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992.

questions.question: What does 'Kinetic lifting' mean?
answers: Using a crane or some other mechanical means
Using a forklift truck or pallet truck
Lifting in the most safe and effective way
Getting a friend to help you with the load

questions.question: What should you do first before lifting or moving a load?
questions.explanation: You or your employer must assess the risk of injury before lifting.

questions.question: Before picking up a load, you should:
answers: Ask a work mate to help you
questions.explanation: You or your employer must assess the risk of injury before lifting.

questions.question: When picking up an object, you should:
questions.explanation: Generally, the legs should do most of the work when lifting a load.

questions.question: When judging 'individual capability' for manual handling, you should assume:
questions.explanation: Assessing ability for manual handling must be done on an individual basis.

questions.question: When an article has to be moved for a long distance, you should:
answers: Get someone else to do it for you
questions.explanation: The use of handling aids can reduce the risk of injury.

questions.question: Which is the correct way to lift a load?
answers: Squat near load, bend back and use leg muscles
Squat near to the load, keeping the back as straight as possible and using leg muscles
Keep feet apart and bend back
Keep feet together and bend back
questions.explanation: Handling techniques which allow the use of relatively strong leg muscles rather than those of the back are preferable.

questions.question: Which would you consider to be generally correct when lifting a load?
answers: Larger loads should be split into smaller loads if possible
Keep the load away from the body
When lifting you should bend your back
The feet should be together and the load lifted at arm's length
questions.explanation: This is a recommendation in HSE guidance (INDG143).

questions.question: If a load has an uneven centre of gravity, how should you lift it?
answers: Keep the heaviest side of the load away from you
Keep the heaviest side of the load on the strongest arm
Keep the heaviest side of the load towards you
Keep the heaviest side of the load on the weakest arm
questions.explanation: There is less risk of injury if a weight's centre of gravity is near the torso.

questions.question: What should you ensure if you suffer an injury through a manual handling operation?
answers: You get paid for the job
You get help and carry on working
questions.explanation: All injuries must be recorded in the company accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: Why should a serious accident be reported to the enforcing authority?
answers: It helps the site find out what caused it
So that the site manager can see who is to blame
So that the company will be held responsible
questions.explanation: Serious accidents (specified injuries or those resulting in an absence of over 7 days) must be reported to the enforcing authority under the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR).

questions.question: What immediate action should you take if you suffer an injury through carrying a load?
answers: Advise your doctor of your injury
Carry on working as best you can
questions.explanation: All injuries must be recorded in the company accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: Under RIDDOR, which one of the following must be reported to the enforcing authority?
answers: Accidents where the injured person wishes to make a claim
Fracture other than to fingers, thumbs or toes
All 'near misses' even if no one is hurt
questions.explanation: This is one of a number of reportable 'specified injuries' and must be reported to the enforcing authority under Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR).

questions.question: Which of the following has the power to examine an accident record?
questions.explanation: HSE inspectors have a range of powers, including this one.

questions.question: Which of the following should be recorded in the accident book following an accident?
answers: The date and time the accident occurred
questions.explanation: The information to be entered in an accident book (BI 510) includes when and where the accident happened, the name and address and occupation of the person who had the accident and details of how the accident happened and the injuries suffered. The weather conditions would only be included if they contributed to the accident.

questions.question: Which one of the following accounts for most accidents each year on construction sites?
questions.explanation: HSE Statistics show clearly that there are more slips, trips and falls than any other types of accident on site.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT classified as a specified injury to a worker under RIDDOR?
questions.explanation: Amputation of an arm, hand, finger, thumb, leg, foot or toe are classified as specified injuries, as are bone fractures other than to fingers, thumbs or toes.

questions.question: Which one of the following should you do if you witness a serious accident on site?
answers: Say nothing in case you get in trouble
Discuss what to do with your workmates
Tell your supervisor what you saw happening
questions.explanation: If the supervisor is aware of an accident he can take steps to prevent a recurrence. The employer also has legal duties to report certain incidents to the enforcing authority.

questions.question: A workmate tells you that he witnessed an accident the previous day and the victim was taken to hospital. He asks you for advice on what he should do. Do you tell them to:
answers: Speak to the site nurse about what he saw
Tell their supervisor that they saw what happened
Telephone the hospital to find out how the injured person is
Say nothing to anyone in case they get someone in trouble
questions.explanation: If the supervisor is aware of an accident he can take steps to prevent a recurrence. The employer also has legal duties to report certain incidents to the enforcing authority.

questions.question: If a person at work suffers an injury (other than a specified injury) due to an accident at work, it is reportable under RIDDOR if they are incapacitated for work for:
questions.explanation: An over-seven-day injury is one which is not a specified injury but results in the injured person being away from work or unable to do the full range of their normal duties for more than seven days (including any days they wouldn't normally be expected to work such as weekends, rest days or holidays) not counting the day of the injury itself.

questions.question: What must an employer do with their accident records following completion of a construction project?
answers: They are sent to the Health and Safety Executive
They are destroyed on site with other non-essential documents
They are kept safe by the employer
They are sent to the employer's insurance company
questions.explanation: Accident records must be kept by an employer for at least three years.

questions.question: At work who would you report a dangerous occurrence to?
questions.explanation: Under RIDDOR, an employer has a legal duty to report certain work-related accidents, but to do this they will need to know that an accident has occurred.

questions.question: Following a reportable dangerous occurrence when must the enforcing authority be informed?
questions.explanation: The enforcing authority must be notified by the quickest practicable means.

questions.question: Accidents causing any injury should always be recorded in:
questions.explanation: All accidents should be recorded in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: Which one of the following is classified as a reportable occupational disease under RIDDOR?
questions.explanation: Certain occupational diseases likely to have been caused or made worse by work are reportable under RIDDOR. This would include occupational asthma where the person's work includes significant or regular exposure to a known respiratory sensitizer.

questions.question: When a person is injured at work, who should enter the details in the accident book?
answers: The injured person or anyone acting for them
questions.explanation: This is the procedure for recording accidents internally in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: If you are involved in a minor accident at work, whose duty is it to report it to site management?
answers: The police, fire or ambulance who attend
The site foreman should report it
questions.explanation: Employers rely on employees to advise them of occurrences at work.

questions.question: You have suffered an accident at work which has made you incapable of your normal work for over 7 days. Which of the following actions MUST be taken by your employer?
answers: The emergency services are asked to attend the site
The relevant enforcing authority is informed
A deduction is made from your wages for days lost
questions.explanation: An over-seven-day injury is one which is not a specified injury but results in the injured person being away from work or unable to do the full range of their normal duties for more than seven days (including any days they wouldn't normally be expected to work such as weekends, rest days or holidays) not counting the day of the injury itself.

questions.question: The collapse of scaffolding is only notifiable to the enforcing authority as a reportable dangerous occurrence when the scaffolding is which one of the following?
questions.explanation: This is one of the requirements of RIDDOR.

questions.question: If there is a fatal accident on site, when must the Health and Safety Executive be informed?
questions.explanation: The enforcing authority must be notified by the quickest practicable means.

questions.question: Under which of the following circumstances should an accident be recorded in the site's accident book?
answers: When an accident causes damage to plant or equipment
Only when a person is injured and will be off work for more than seven days
When the injury is serious enough for first aid to be needed
When an accident causes injury to an employee while at work
questions.explanation: An accident causing an injury to an employee at work should be recorded in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: Which of the following have to be entered into the accident book?
answers: Only accidents causing time off work
questions.explanation: An accident causing an injury to an employee at work should be recorded in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: Under which of the following circumstances must injury accidents be recorded in the accident book?
answers: Only if you break a bone
Only if you have time off work
Only if you need to go to hospital
questions.explanation: An accident causing an injury to an employee at work should be recorded in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: An entry must be made in the accident book when:
answers: The person has been off sick for over seven days
An accident causes personal injury to an employee
The severity of the accident may result in a compensation claim
questions.explanation: An accident causing an injury to an employee at work should be recorded in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: Which of the following MUST be recorded in an accident book after you have had an accident?
questions.explanation: The information to be entered in an accident book (BI 510) includes when and where the accident happened, the name, address and occupation of the person who had the accident and details of how the accident happened and the injuries suffered.

questions.question: Which of the following can you learn from an accident?
answers: A combination of human error and mechanical failure always causes injury
Ideas on how you would prevent it happening again
That mechanical failures are most dangerous
How human error is always a cause
questions.explanation: An accident investigation should not only assess the cause, but also how similar accidents can be prevented in the future.

questions.question: Could making an entry in the accident book help you if you later make a claim for compensation?
answers: Only if it is a serious injury
Only in the event of a fatality
questions.explanation: This is laid down in Social Security Legislation.

questions.question: Why is it important to report 'near miss' accidents to your employer?
answers: To make the figures look good
So lessons can be learned, preventing an accident next time
So that someone can be disciplined
questions.explanation: HSE advises that 'near misses' should be investigated to prevent their recurrence.

questions.question: Who should you report serious accidents to?
questions.explanation: If the supervisor is aware of an accident he can take steps to prevent a recurrence. The employer also has legal duties to report certain incidents to the enforcing authority.

questions.question: What is the aim of carrying out an accident investigation?
answers: To determine the cause(s) and prevent similar accidents
To establish what injuries were sustained
To find out who is at fault
To establish the cost of any damage incurred
questions.explanation: An accident investigation should not only assess the cause, but also how similar accidents can be prevented in the future.

questions.question: You have witnessed a serious accident on your site and are interviewed by an HSE inspector. You should:
answers: Tell the inspector what your mates said you should say
Ask your supervisor what you should say to the inspector
Co-operate fully with the inspector and tell them exactly what you saw
questions.explanation: This is good practice, but it can also be an offence to withhold important information from an inspector.

questions.question: When working in dusty conditions, what of the following would give the LEAST level of protection?
questions.explanation: Protection factors are given in HSE publication HSG53 'Respiratory protective equipment at work – A practical guide'.

questions.question: In hot weather which one of the following is correct with regard to safety helmets?
answers: You can take off your helmet while working inside the building
You must continue to wear your helmet
You can drill holes in your safety hat for ventilation
You do not need to wear your helmet
questions.explanation: On construction sites, despite controls being put in place, there will always be situations where a risk of head injury remains. Taking off your helmet would put you at a much greater risk of a head injury and any unauthorised modification would be in breach of legal requirements and could render the helmet next to useless.

questions.question: Which one of the following should you do if your personal protective equipment (PPE) is damaged?
answers: Report to your Supervisor without delay
Reduce the amount of time you use it
questions.explanation: Employees are required to report any defective PPE to their employer (PPE at Work Regulations 1992, Regulation 7).

questions.question: If personal protective equipment (PPE) is defective, what should you do?
answers: Complain to the Health and Safety Inspector
Get your workmate to mend it if possible
Repair if possible and continue to use it
questions.explanation: Employees are required to report any defective PPE to their employer (PPE at Work Regulations 1992, Regulation 7).

questions.question: In normal use, what item of PPE is NOT essential for the operator of a cartridge-operated tool, such as a nail gun?
questions.explanation: Wellingtons do not offer protection against the specific risks associated with the use of a cartridge-operated tool, although safety footwear must always be worn when there is a risk of a foot injury.

questions.question: Can you opt out of wearing personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answers: Yes, by informing the site supervisor
Yes, by writing officially to your employer
questions.explanation: You cannot legally 'opt out' of being protected from significant risks at work. This includes wearing the necessary PPE.

questions.question: What is the most important item of personal protective equipment (PPE) when working on or near a highway?
questions.explanation: A high visibility vest is the most important of PPE however, the other items of PPE may also be required.

questions.question: If you are drilling into concrete with a masonry drill, in which one of the following circumstances will you need to wear eye protection?
answers: Only if the drill is bigger than 10mm
Not if drilling into the floor
questions.explanation: Suitable eye protection must always be worn when working with power-driven tools where chippings are likely to fly or abrasive materials could be propelled.

questions.question: When must you wear all personal protective equipment (PPE) provided by your employer?
questions.explanation: Under the PPE at Work Regulations 1992, employees must wear PPE as instructed.

questions.question: When MUST an employer provide their employees with personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answers: When they may be exposed to a risk to their health and safety which cannot be controlled another way
If the client or main contractor specifies it in the contract
questions.explanation: As required by regulation 4 of the PPE Regulations.

questions.question: What type of eye protection would you wear when using a cartridge-operated tool, such as a nail gun?
questions.explanation: When using a cartridge-operated tool, such as a nail gun, shatter proof goggles should be worn.

questions.question: Which of the following must your safety helmet comply with to meet with the requirements of the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations?
answers: It can be adjusted to suit your head size
It is a good visible colour
It has a label with your name on it
It is less than 1 year old
questions.explanation: An assessment of the suitability of head protection would include consideration of whether it can be adjusted to suit the individual who is to wear it, that it is compatible with the work to be done and that it is comfortable to wear.

questions.question: In which of the following ways should you wear your safety helmet?
answers: With the peak raised to deflect falling material
With the helmet back to front
With the peak raised to give good vision
Square on your head, properly adjusted
questions.explanation: Any item of personal protective equipment must be used in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, which will include how to correctly fit and wear it and what its limitations are.

questions.question: When an employee has been issued with eye protection, what are their duties under the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations?
answers: To ensure that they are the right type of protector
Not to loan the equipment to other operatives
To use the protection in accordance with training and instruction
To pay for replacement of lost eye protection
questions.explanation: Regulation 10(2) requires that every employee shall use any PPE in accordance with the training and instruction received.

questions.question: When should you wear safety footwear on site?
answers: When there is a risk of a foot injury
Only if the site conditions are wet
questions.explanation: Suitable safety footwear should be worn if there is a risk of injury from objects falling onto the foot or sharp objects, such as nails, penetrating the sole.

questions.question: With regard to the use of personal protective equipment (PPE), which one of the following statements is true?
answers: If you do not use the personal protective equipment (PPE) provided you will probably not come to any harm
Personal protective equipment (PPE) protects only the user from the dangers present
Personal protective equipment (PPE) need only be provided if it is not too expensive
Personal protective equipment (PPE) need only be used if it is available
questions.explanation: PPE is there to protect the individual. Wearing PPE does not protect other people nearby.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE when an employer issues personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answers: The employer can charge you for the full cost of it
The employer cannot charge you for it
The employer can charge you for up to half the cost of it
The employer can only charge you for it if you lose or damage it
questions.explanation: Employers cannot charge for PPE such as hard hats, gloves, required by law (and the bulk of PPE is required by law).

questions.question: Which one of the following must apply to any hard hat provided?
answers: It is CE or UKCA marked
It is less than 5 years old
It is less than 1 year old
It is less than 2 years old
questions.explanation: All PPE should be CE – marked, indicating that it meets the basic health and safety requirements.

questions.question: When using personal protective equipment (PPE) legally you must do which of the following?
answers: Not interfere with it or misuse it
Replace it at your own expense if it is damaged
Return it to the manufacturer when damaged
Clean it properly once a week
questions.explanation: Interfering with or misusing items provided in the interests of health, safety or welfare is an offence under the HSW Act 1974 (Section 8).

questions.question: If it is necessary for an employee to use personal protective equipment, who has a duty to provide it?
questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the PPE at Work Regulations 1992 (Regulation 4).

questions.question: When should a safety helmet be worn on site?
answers: At all times unless there is no foreseeable risk of injury to the head other than by falling
When you are out in the open air
When walking to and from a place of work
questions.explanation: The circumstances when there is no foreseeable risk of head injury from falling or swinging objects or striking the head against something will be very limited in most construction work.

questions.question: A colleague has drilled holes in the top of their safety helmet because the weather is hot. Is this:
answers: Acceptable if the holes are small
questions.explanation: Interfering with or misusing items provided in the interests of health, safety or welfare is an offence under the HSW Act 1974 (section 8).

questions.question: Who has a duty to provide PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) for use by an employee?
questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the PPE at Work Regulations 1992 (Regulation 4).

questions.question: When would it be appropriate to wear a bump-cap instead of a safety helmet?
answers: When there is no foreseeable risk of injury from falling or swinging objects
questions.explanation: Industrial scalp protectors (bump caps) can protect against striking fixed obstacles, scalping or entanglements. They do not provide suitable protection against falling or swinging objects.

questions.question: How can you protect your eyesight while working on site?
answers: By not looking directly at what you are doing
By wearing the correct type of eye protection

questions.question: When is head protection required to be worn on a construction site to comply with the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations?
answers: At all times except by those who are self employed
Only when you feel like it
At all times unless you are working on scaffold
At all times unless there is no foreseeable risk of injury to the head other than by falling
questions.explanation: If there is no risk of injury to the head, then hard hats are not required by law. However, on construction sites, despite controls being in place, there will almost always be situations where a risk of head injury remains and require head protection to be worn. Site rules will also require the wearing of head protection other than in any designated safe areas.

questions.question: Why should a high visibility vest be worn when working on roads?
answers: So road users and plant operators can see you
Because you were told to do so
Because it will keep you warm
So that your mates can see you
questions.explanation: Many workers are struck and injured, often seriously, by moving vehicles.

questions.question: When considering what measures to take to protect people's health and safety, PPE should always be regarded as:
answers: The best way to tackle the job
questions.explanation: Engineering controls and safe systems of work should always be considered first.

questions.question: Exposure to asbestos fibres may cause which one of the following?
questions.explanation: Breathing in asbestos fibres can also lead to a number of other diseases, including lung cancer and mesothelioma.

questions.question: Asbestos is suspected in the workplace, during renovation do you:
questions.explanation: Competent advice must be sought, to prevent exposure to the worker or others, either at the time, or subsequently.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about asbestos is TRUE?
answers: Asbestos is not really a hazard to health
White asbestos is safe to use
All asbestos can be a hazard to health
Only brown and blue asbestos are a hazard to health
questions.explanation: All forms of asbestos can cause fatal diseases.

questions.question: While working you discover material you think could be asbestos. What should you do?
answers: Clear any dust and fragments, put them in a bin then carry on working
Stop working immediately and report your suspicions to your supervisor
Dampen the material to prevent further dust being created, then carry on working
questions.explanation: It is essential to stop work if asbestos is found or suspected, and await competent advice on what to do next.

questions.question: Can you tell by the smell of a product whether it is likely to cause harm?
answers: Only if you have been trained
questions.explanation: Many harmful substances have no smell.

questions.question: How would you recognise a hazardous substance?
answers: By a symbol on the container
The colour of the label on the container
It will be in a suitable container
questions.explanation: A supplier of a packaged hazardous substance must include a label on the packaging incorporating one or more hazard symbols alerting users to the dangers posed by the chemical.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT cause skin problems?
questions.explanation: Asbestos is potentially very harmful if inhaled, but does not affect the skin significantly.

questions.question: When an assessment of hazardous substances has been carried out under the COSHH Regulations, the risks and control measures should be explained to:
answers: The person in charge of the stores
questions.explanation: All those working with the hazardous substances in question need to know about any risks.

questions.question: If your hands are very dirty, what should you use to get them clean?
questions.explanation: The other substances can remove natural oils from the skin.

questions.question: The presence of rats on site creates a risk of catching Weil's disease. What is the EASIEST PRACTICAL MEASURE that you can take to discourage the presence of rats?
answers: Avoid leaving scraps of food lying about
Contact the local Environmental Health Officer
Bring a large cat on site
questions.explanation: The easiest solution is to avoid leaving food around, since this is what attracts vermin.

questions.question: Why is personal hygiene so important?
answers: Because the COSHH regulations require it
To protect your own and others' health
To stop you catching something nasty

questions.question: If you have been handling lead, how is it most likely to get into your blood stream?
answers: By not reporting the matter to the HSE
By not using the correct safety footwear
By not washing your hands before eating
questions.explanation: The route into the body is ingestion, normally from lead contamination on the hands.

questions.question: The number of toilets provided on site depends on:
answers: The type of work being completed
The ratio of male and female workers on site
The duration of the work on site
The number of personnel on site
questions.explanation: Guidance on the provision of welfare facilities is given in HSE publication 'Health and Safety in Construction'.

questions.question: Which of the following is not required to be provided under the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations?
questions.explanation: Guidance on the provision of welfare facilities as required by CDM is given in HSE publication 'Health and Safety in Construction'.

questions.question: The extended use of powered hand-held tools and equipment may lead to which medical condition?
questions.explanation: Hand-arm vibration can cause a range of conditions (including vibration white finger) collectively known as hand-arm vibration syndrome, as well as diseases such as carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.question: What must your employer do if the daily personal noise exposure is at or exceeds 85 db(A)?
answers: Provide hearing protection to those employees who ask for it
Issue hearing protection to those exposed and ensure that it is worn
Tell employees to buy their own hearing protection
Report it to the Health and Safety Executive
questions.explanation: This is an interim measure under the Control of Noise at Work Regulations 2005 when the daily personal noise exposure is at or exceeds the upper exposure action value of 85 dB(A). Exposure should subsequently be reduced by implementing organizational or technical measures.

questions.question: What are the lower and upper action values with regard to daily personal noise exposure, as defined in the Control of Noise at Work Regulations 2005?
questions.explanation: Daily personal noise exposure is the average noise level experienced by an individual over an 8 hour period.

questions.question: At or above what level of daily personal noise exposure does an employer have to provide hearing protection if it is requested by an employee?
questions.explanation: This is one of the duties of employers under the Control of Noise at Work Regulations 2005 when the lower exposure action value of 80 dB(A) is reached or exceeded.

questions.question: The effects of damage to your hearing by long-term exposure to high noise levels:
answers: Can be corrected by an operation
Will be reduced when you change jobs
Can be reversed to near normal with time
questions.explanation: Hearing damage due to long-term noise exposure is irreversible.

questions.question: Hearing protection should be worn:
questions.explanation: Employees must wear hearing protectors when exposed at or above the upper exposure action values and within hearing protection zones.

questions.question: Wearing suitable hearing protection:
answers: Brings noise down to an acceptable level
questions.explanation: Hearing protection still allows some noise to reach the ear, but, if it has been correctly chosen, will reduce noise levels to an acceptable level.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the recommended means of protecting your hearing?
questions.explanation: The others are not considered to be suitable types of hearing protection.

questions.question: Which of the following would NOT reduce the risks from hand-arm vibration when using a hammer action tool?
answers: Selecting the lowest vibration tool that is suitable and which can do the work efficiently
Wearing gloves to keep the hands warm
Working as a team to share the work out
Making sure one person does all the work with the tool
questions.explanation: Where tools require constant or frequent use, rotas will avoid individuals having long exposure to vibration. The use of low-vibration tools and keeping the hands warm in cold conditions will also reduce the risks.

questions.question: Which of the following animals can carry Weil's disease?
questions.explanation: Weil's disease is a serious and sometimes fatal infection that can be transmitted to humans by contact with infected rats. Another form of Leptospirosis infection can be transmitted from cattle to humans.

questions.question: You are most likely to catch Weil's disease (Leptospirosis) if you:
answers: Work near wet ground, waterways or sewers
questions.explanation: Anyone who is exposed to rat urine is at risk, particularly sewer workers and farmers. Those in contact with canal or river water are also at risk.

questions.question: What should you do if the toilets on your site are continually dirty?
answers: Ignore the problem – its normal on a construction site
Make sure you tell someone who can sort it out
Find some cleaning materials and clean it up yourself
Ask in a nearby cafe or pub if you can use their toilets
questions.explanation: How often welfare facilities on site require cleaning will depend on the number of people on site and how quickly they get dirty. The person in control of the site should make sure someone is responsible for keeping the facilities clean and tidy.

questions.question: Excessive sunlight on bare skin can cause which serious health problem?
questions.explanation: Ultraviolet rays in sunlight can cause sunburn and premature ageing of the skin. The most serious effect, however, is an increased chance of developing skin cancer.

questions.question: An emergency route(s) must be provided on construction sites to ensure:
answers: Safe passage to the open air
Safe passage to the rest area
Safe passage to a secure place of safety
Safe passage to the ground from height

questions.question: What action should you take if you discover a fire?
answers: Leave it because you will get the blame
Carry on working if it is safe to do so
Extinguish the fire without raising the alarm
questions.explanation: Raising the alarm will reduce the risk to others, particularly if the fire spreads.

questions.question: If there had been a small fire, who should you report it to?
questions.explanation: The supervisor should be aware, so that further preventative measures can be considered.

questions.question: If you discover a fire at work, what should you do first:
answers: Use a fire extinguisher to put it out
Run around looking for an alarm to sound
Raise the alarm and warn fellow workers
questions.explanation: Raising the alarm will reduce the risk to others, particularly if the fire spreads.

questions.question: What is a fire assembly point?
answers: The place to go when the fire alarm sounds
A place where the fire brigade goes to
A place where fire extinguishers are kept
The place where the fire alarm is
questions.explanation: It is essential that people go to a place of safety, where supervisors or fire marshals know where they are, in the event of a fire.

questions.question: Where would you go in the event of a fire?
answers: To the canteen for a cup of tea
To the fire to see what is going on
questions.explanation: It is essential that people go to a place of safety, where supervisors or fire marshals know where they are, in the event of a fire.

questions.question: What should you do if you hear the fire alarm?
answers: Ignore it because it might be someone playing around
Evacuate the premises to a designated place of safety
Go towards the sound to find out what is going on
questions.explanation: It is essential that people go to a place of safety, where supervisors or fire marshals know where they are, in the event of a fire.

questions.question: All new fire extinguishers are coloured red or of bright self-coloured metal. How do you know the difference between types?
answers: A different colour panel or band is on the body of the extinguishers
During site induction, you will be told where the different types of extinguishers are
The weight and shape of the extinguisher
The type of extinguisher is written on a sign next to it
questions.explanation: Different coloured bands show extinguisher types e.g. black for CO2 and blue for dry powder.

questions.question: A black-labelled fire extinguisher contains:
What is a blue-labelled fire extinguisher filled with?
Which fire extinguisher should not be used on flammable liquid fires?
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids spread if attacked by water extinguishers.

questions.question: What colour is a water filled fire extinguisher, or its label?
When discharging carbon dioxide fire extinguishers, the nozzle:
questions.explanation: The expansion of CO2 gas coming out of the nozzle causes rapid cooling.

questions.question: For fires involving spilled petrol, which types of fire extinguisher could you use?
answers: Foam, carbon dioxide or dry powder
Water, carbon dioxide or dry powder
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids, such as petrol, spread if attacked by water extinguishers.

questions.question: Which types of fire extinguishers should be used on electrical fires?
questions.explanation: Liquids should not be used, since they may conduct electricity.

questions.question: A red-labelled fire extinguisher should NOT be used:
answers: Where there is a risk of electrocution
questions.explanation: Red denotes water. Liquids should not be used on electrical fires, since they can conduct electricity.

questions.question: A workmate burns their hand on a piece of very hot metal. What should you do first?
answers: Rub some cream or Vaseline into the burn
Cover the burn with something dry
Warn other people about the piece of hot metal
Put their hand in cold water if it is available
questions.explanation: Burns need immediate and sustained cooling.

questions.question: Which of the following items should not be in a first aid box?
questions.explanation: Drugs must not be kept in a first aid box (Health and Safety guidance note INDG 214).

questions.question: How often should a first-aider qualified in First Aid at Work (FAW) or Emergency First Aid at Work (EFAW) receive retraining?
questions.explanation: First Aid at Work (FAW) and Emergency First Aid at Work (EFAW) certificates are valid for three years and first-aiders are required to undertake retraining at the end of this period. However, the HSE also strongly recommends that first-aiders undertake annual (half-day) refresher training.

questions.question: If you came across an injury on site, what is the first thing you should do?
answers: Tell the casualty to visit their doctor
Try and find out what happened
questions.explanation: Competent first-aid treatment is essential, and should be summoned immediately.

questions.question: An employee has a fall and is obviously unconscious. What is the FIRST thing you should do?
answers: Find out if there were any witnesses
Try to protect them from any further injury
Put them in the recovery position
questions.explanation: Competent first-aid treatment is essential, and should be summoned immediately.

questions.question: A labourer gets an electric shock; looks a bit pale but says they are alright. What should you do?
answers: Tell them to report it to their supervisor
Go and check the electrics so it cannot happen again
See if they want a drink or a cigarette
questions.explanation: Competent first-aid treatment is essential, and should be summoned immediately.

questions.question: Which of the following must an employer consider when making provisions for first aid?
answers: How much working space will be wasted
Whether the local ambulance service can be used
questions.explanation: Employers must match first-aid provision to the nature of risks at work.

questions.question: In an on-site emergency, which of the following must a first-aider NOT do?
answers: Give medicines to patients without authorisation
questions.explanation: First-aid is concerned with preserving life and limb, and first-aiders are not trained to dispense medical treatments.

questions.question: If someone has fallen over and has stopped breathing, what is the first thing you should do?
answers: Try to give the casualty a drink
Try to start the casualty breathing
questions.explanation: Do not delay in sending for help; then try to start the casualty breathing.

questions.question: If someone has fallen off a ladder and they say their leg is broken, what should you do?
answers: Help them to the cabin or mess hut
Move the ladder so no-one trips over it
questions.explanation: Competent first-aid treatment is essential, and should be summoned immediately.

questions.question: Your workmate suddenly gets a foreign body in the eye. What should you do?
answers: Take your workmate to the supervisor
Use a clean handkerchief to try and remove it
Wash your hands before touching your mate's face
questions.explanation: Competent first-aid treatment is essential, and should be summoned immediately.

questions.question: A person nearly collapses complaining of stomach pains. What should you do?
answers: Go and find them something to drink
Help them to find somewhere comfortable to sit
Ask them if they want something to eat
questions.explanation: Competent first-aid treatment is essential, and should be summoned immediately.

questions.question: A workmate lifting a big box suddenly shouts 'oh, my back' and drops the box. What should you do?
answers: Tell them to leave it for someone else to lift
Help them to lift the box
Find them somewhere comfortable to sit and rest
questions.explanation: The priority for any back injury is to obtain first-aid advice, in order to prevent further damage.

questions.question: What should you do immediately if you get a small cut on a finger whilst at work?
answers: Ask your employer to report it to the HSE
questions.explanation: It is important to obtain first-aid to prevent further harm (e.g. through infection). It should also be recorded in the accident book (BI 510).

questions.question: In an emergency situation at work you should do what?
answers: Ensure your work mates are all accounted for
questions.explanation: A site emergency plan should have been drawn up and you should be familiar with the emergency procedure.

questions.question: What does the sound of a siren on-site normally indicate?
The purpose of fire-stopping in a building is to:
answers: Delay the passage of fire and smoke through openings in walls and floors
questions.explanation: Fire-stopping is a passive fire protection measure used to seal any openings created in a fire resistance-rated wall or floor assembly, e.g. to allow pipes or wiring systems to pass through. During fire conditions this will impede the spread of fire and smoke.

questions.question: What are fire-stops designed to do?
answers: Protect services (such as wiring systems) against fire damage
Delay the passage of fire and smoke through openings in walls and floors
questions.explanation: Fire-stops are designed to maintain the fireproofing of a wall or floor assembly. Fire-stopping delays the spread of fire and, generally, the spread of smoke as well.

questions.question: In addition to preserving fire separation between areas of a building, which other important fire safety function can fire-stopping achieve?
questions.explanation: During a fire it is essential that the load-bearing capacity of elements of the building structure are maintained until occupants have escaped. Timber studs, joists or 'I' beams, for example, may only have a short survival time if exposed to fire and may rely on linings, such as a plasterboard ceiling, for fire-resistance. Services passing through such linings should therefore be fire-stopped.

questions.question: Intumescent materials used to provide fire-stopping are designed to:
questions.explanation: A limited number of fire-resistant materials may be used to provide fire-stopping. These include intumescent products, which are designed to expand and provide fire-stopping when subjected to heat. Examples include intumescent 'pillows'.

questions.question: What should you do if you disturb fire-stopping around a wiring system penetrating a wall or floor whilst carrying out work?
answers: Nail a piece of wood over any gaps
Ensure that the fire-stopping is reinstated to the necessary standard as soon as possible
Fill any holes or gaps with squashed newspaper
questions.explanation: It is essential that the integrity of fire compartments is maintained during the construction of buildings and on their completion. Compromising compartmentation, such as failing to adequately fire-stop (seal) openings for services to pass through, can undermine fire precautions catastrophically. Only a limited range of products are suitable and they must be correctly applied to provide the required degree of fire-stopping.

questions.question: If you discover a hole or gap in a fire rated wall or floor that has not been fire-stopped, what should you do?
answers: Report it to your supervisor without delay
Ignore it unless it is causing a draught
Cover the hole or gap with insulating tape
Use decorators' sealant to fill the gap
questions.explanation: Supervisors need to be made aware of any observed inadequacies in fire-stopping - which can undermine fire precautions catastrophically during the construction of buildings and on their completion. Only a limited range of products are suitable and they must be correctly applied to provide the required degree of fire-stopping.

questions.question: Which one of the following is associated with a Higher Risk Building (HRBs) in England?
answers: At least 18 metres in height or seven storeys
At least 15 metres in height or seven storeys
At least 15 metres in height or six storeys
At least 18 metres in height or six storeys
questions.explanation: At least 18 meters in height or seven storeys is the height at which the Building Safety Regulator regime will apply in England.

questions.question: For a holistic approach to fire safety - to plan for all aspects of fire safety - the three main areas that need to be considered are design, construction and...
questions.explanation: Design, construction and maintenance are the main aspects to be considered as part of a holistic view to fire safety covering all elements to cover all aspects.

questions.question: Which of the following materials provide the least effective fire resistance?
questions.explanation: Timber or wood has a low ignition point and can be highly flammable, generally considered to have poor fire resistance.

questions.question: When man-made substances, such as rubber, burn, the colour of the smoke is typically:
questions.explanation: The black colour of smoke from burning man-made substances, including rubber, is primarily due to incomplete combustion of carbon-based materials, and soot particles suspended in the air making the smoke appear black.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a benefit of a 'stay put' strategy for fire evacuation in high risk buildings?
answers: It slows the fire fighters' response to a fire
It reduces communication between occupants and emergency services
You reduce the risk of entering a smoky corridor and being overcome by smoke
It allows lifts to be used more effectively
questions.explanation: A 'stay-put' strategy is designed to prevent injury, reduce panic, and reduce smoke inhalation which could cause injury or fatalities.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a requirement of a protected escape route?
questions.explanation: Although emergency lighting systems are mandated to provide adequate illumination in escape routes, this does not include infra-red lights specifically.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not an area of competence?
questions.explanation: Competence is broadly defined as the skills, knowledge, experience, and behaviours of an individual.

questions.question: What is a key consideration for individuals to ensure safety at work?
answers: Pushing personal limits to complete a job at any cost
Having a go at jobs without proper training
Recognising the limitations of competence and not exceeding your own limitations
Ignoring boundaries to complete a job in the quickest manner possible
questions.explanation: Competence includes the recognition and awareness of the limitations of your own competence, and not undertaking jobs or tasks for which you haven't received proper training as this will lead to unsafe and potentially dangerous practices.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a consequence of poor workmanship?
questions.explanation: A lack of competence and poor workmanship can lead to increased servicing and maintenance requirements, and increased hazards as a result.

questions.question: What is CROSS-UK?
answers: A branch of the British Red Cross for Construction Workers
An online forum for workers to complain about their employers
A confidential reporting system to report on fire and structural safety issues
A charity that supplies work equipment to apprentices
questions.explanation: CROSS-UK is Collaborative Reporting for Safer Structures UK – a confidential reporting system which allows professionals working in the built environment to report on fire or structural safety issues.

questions.question: Most deaths on site are caused by:
questions.explanation: Although the other dangers can kill or cause injury, falling from height is the bigger cause of fatalities.

questions.question: The type of accident that kills most construction site workers is:
questions.explanation: Although the other dangers can kill or cause injury, falling from height is the biggest cause of fatalities.

questions.question: The main cause of deaths on construction sites is…
How many people should be working on a ladder at one time?
answers: One on each section of an extension ladder
Three if it is long enough
questions.explanation: Only one person should be working on a ladder, although another person may be footing it, for extra stability.

questions.question: Ladders should be set at a slope of approximately:
Why should aluminium ladders be kept away from wet lime or cement?
answers: The ladder may become statically charged
questions.explanation: Aluminium can corrode in certain situations, notably if in prolonged contact with lime or cement.

questions.question: Before being used, a ladder should be inspected:
questions.explanation: The user needs to be satisfied that the ladder is in a safe condition before using it.

questions.question: Ladders should be:
answers: Tied or footed AND at the right angle AND in good condition
questions.explanation: All the measures listed are required to reduce the risk of falls.

questions.question: A ladder giving access to a scaffold can generally be safely used, provided that:
answers: The foot of the ladder is firmly wedged
It does not move when you climb up it
Any broken rungs are clearly marked
It is tied and extends at least 1 metre above the platform
questions.explanation: Access ladders should extend at least 1 metre above the landing point to provide a safe handhold.

questions.question: What is the ideal angle for a ladder against a wall and floor?
answers: One metre up for every metre out from the wall
One metre up for every two metres out from the wall
Two metres up for every metre out from the wall
Four metres up for every metre out from the wall
questions.explanation: The correct angle for a ladder is 75 degrees, which can be judged using the angle indicator marked on the stiles of some ladders or using the 1 in 4 rule.

questions.question: The rung of a wooden ladder has started to split, what should you do?
answers: Do not use it, tell your supervisor
Jump on it to see if it holds your weight
questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: Ladders should not be painted because:
answers: The paint will make them slippery to use
The paint may not be suitable on metal parts of the ladder
The paint may cover a defect or damaged part of the ladder

questions.question: When can you work from a ladder?
answers: For short periods and then only if it is safe to do so
When not being used for access
questions.explanation: Ladders are primarily means of access, not workplaces. They can be worked from, but only if the use of other, more suitable, work equipment is not appropriate and the task is of low risk and of short duration.

questions.question: When working above public areas, what should be considered?
answers: Keeping the areas open to the public
questions.explanation: There is a significant risk to the public from falling materials, if this is not considered before and during work.

questions.question: A scaffold tower must be erected by:
answers: The hire company who supply it
questions.explanation: There are a number of organizations that provide training for the safe erection and use of scaffold towers.

questions.question: What is the minimum height of the top guard-rail of a scaffold above the edge from which someone is liable to fall?
questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the Work at Height Regulations 2005.

questions.question: A working platform used for construction work, and from which a person could fall 2 metres or more, must not be used unless it has been inspected (and a report is subsequently prepared) by a competent person:
questions.explanation: Under these specific circumstances a report is required to be prepared by the competent person and given to the person for whom the inspection was done (e.g. the site manager). This is in addition to the more general requirement to inspect equipment for work at height: prior to use in that position (or site if it is mobile); following exceptional circumstances (e.g. high winds); and at suitable intervals.

questions.question: On a mobile elevating work platform, what should you attach your safety harness to?
answers: A secure anchorage point inside the platform
A strong part of the structure you are working on
questions.explanation: The priority is to stay within the platform (which is the safest place) and in any event you cannot be sure of the strength of other fixtures.

questions.question: You have been asked to operate a cherry-picker (mobile elevated work platform) when it is very windy. What should your FIRST consideration be?
answers: Wear a safety harness and clip it to the structure that you are working on
Does the wind-speed make it unsafe to use the machine
Wear an extra layer of clothing to keep warm
Tie all light-weight objects to the hand-rails of the basket
questions.explanation: The priority in safety is eliminating risk at source – in this case by not working in dangerous conditions – rather than trying to stay safe by using protective equipment.

questions.question: If you have to work at height and it is not possible to erect a scaffold, or use any other type of working platform or mobile elevating work platform, then you should:
answers: Work without fall protection, provided you have a mate with you
Wear a harness and lanyard at all times if you fall
Work without fall protection, provided the weather is not too windy
Work without fall protection at all times when no one else is about
questions.explanation: The harness will greatly reduce the likelihood of injury.

questions.question: When working on a roof that has fragile, clear-plastic panels, what is the best way of preventing falls through the panels?
answers: Make sure that everyone is told where the panels are and to avoid treading on them
Cover the fragile panels with a strong material and secure the covers to stop them being dislodged
Remove the panels carefully to leave an open space
It shouldn't be necessary to do anything, everyone knows the dangers
questions.explanation: Protection from falling through openings and fragile roof lights can be provided by barriers or with covers which can be secured or labelled with a warning.

questions.question: When working on a roof that has fragile, clear-plastic panels, what is the best way of preventing falls through the panels?
answers: It is safe to walk on the purlins
Walk straight across the roof to where you need to get to
As long as you avoid any fragile areas it is safe
Crawling boards should always be used
questions.explanation: Fragile roofs must be made safe to work on, before work commences.

questions.question: Half the deaths on construction sites are caused by which one of the following?
questions.explanation: This is shown by HSE statistics.

questions.question: What should you do if your work activity requires you to wear a full body safety harness and one is not available?
answers: Make a harness from items found on site
Carry on working and hope that everything will be alright
Borrow a harness from a colleague
Stop work immediately and tell your supervisor that you do not have the correct PPE
questions.explanation: Always advise the supervisor if you do not have the correct PPE.

questions.question: Under what circumstances do the Work at Height Regulations permit a stepladder to be used on site?
answers: Provided you can't fall 2 metres or more
Only when a risk assessment shows that safer alternatives have been ruled out and the task is of low risk and of short duration
questions.explanation: The WAH Regulations have not banned the use of ladders or stepladders, but they should be used sensibly.

questions.question: What is the best method of securing a ladder?
answers: Tying it to a suitable point
Using an effective ladder stability device
Wedging the ladder (e.g. against a wall)
questions.explanation: Tying the ladder is the safest option, making sure both stiles are tied.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the POOREST method of securing a ladder?
answers: Securing the base of the ladder
questions.explanation: Footing a ladder is the last resort and should be avoided. Other more suitable access equipment should be used where practicable.

questions.question: Prior to moving a mobile tower scaffold, the platform height should reduced to a maximum of:
questions.explanation: This figure is quoted in guidance published by the HSE and PASMA. Checks should also be made that there are no obstructions overhead, the ground is firm, level and free from potholes, it is not too windy and there are no people or materials on the tower.

questions.question: What do the letters SWL stand for?
questions.explanation: Machinery and accessories for lifting loads should be clearly marked to indicate their safe working loads.

questions.question: Who should operate plant and equipment on site?
answers: Only people over 18 years of age
An employee holding a full driving licence
questions.explanation: Never operate plant or equipment unless you have been trained and are authorised to do so.

questions.question: What hazard is created when the head of a cold chisel mushrooms?
questions.explanation: This question is looking for the hazard, which is the situation that can cause harm to people.

questions.question: Any damaged equipment must be:
answers: Locked up so no one can use it
questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: The electric drill you are about to use has a faulty on/off switch. What action should you take?
answers: Find another machine and carry on working
Remove it from use and tell your supervisor
Tape the switch on to keep it running and carry on working
questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: The power hand tool you are about to use has burn marks visible on the cable. What should you do?
answers: Tape over the affected area and continue
Tell your supervisor about the defect and do not use the tool
Obtain another machine and carry on, but don't tell anyone
Carry on and get the job done
questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: Your supervisor asks you to use a powered hand-tool which has a rotating blade. You notice that the guard is missing from the blade. What do you do?
answers: Use the tool anyway, you haven't had an accident with it before
Remove it from use and tell your supervisor
Try to make an improvised guard yourself
Contact the manufacturer of the tool
questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: Hand and power tools must be:
answers: The best that you can buy
Suitable for the task and regularly inspected
questions.explanation: Tools must not create a risk to the user or others. This means they must be suitable and kept in good condition. This requires inspection before use.

questions.question: When should visual checks of portable hand-held equipment be made by the user?
questions.explanation: The user needs to be satisfied that the tool has no obvious defect before use.

questions.question: What precaution should you take before adjusting an electrical tool?
answers: Check the lead is not twisted or knotted
Wear safety footwear with steel toe caps
Wear the correct personal protective equipment
questions.explanation: Do not adjust tools which could still be live or operate.

questions.question: An electric drill is to be used. Before use, who should carry out a check on the tool?
questions.explanation: The user needs to be satisfied that the tool has no obvious defect before use.

questions.question: What action should you take if an electric drill cuts out while you are using it?
answers: Put it back into the tool box
Switch the power off and on
Remove it from use and tell your supervisor
